To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

xi N
o
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
For his returne./

page.lettertext:
fol.187r
May it please yo
r
good L. I thought before this,
that yo
w
had bin moved by a fitter person then
my self, for yo
r
honorable furtherance in a mater
of some suite, w
ch
I have formerly presented.
Howbeit
e parties absence both from
London
and
the
Court
doth force me nowe againe to make
mine owne petition, beseeching yo
w
most humbly
to remember her
Ma
tie
of my long continuance
in this place, and to intreat her of her gratious
favo
r
, to licence my returne. for besides many
hazardes w
ch
I have incurred in my privat
poore estate, by reason of mine absence, w
ch
I
was willinger yo
w
should knowe by some
other them my self, and by speeches then by
writing, It hath pleased God of late to calle
away my
father,
to whome I had commended
my domesticall affaires, and
e care of all
my state: and by meanes of his decease, it is
at this present muche more entangled then before,
and further dommages sustened, then I will
troble yo
r
L. to heare reported. But no-
thing doubting but
at yo
r
favo
r
unto me is
e same that it hath bin, and
at her Ma
tie
will be moved w
t
yo
r
L. good persuasion
I relie upon it wholy,
and take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. N
o
10 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Count Maurice
is adver-
tised by sundrie l
res
,
at
e
D. of Parma
for certaine is gone
towardes
Mons
in
Henault,
and
so into
France,
having w
t
him
14 Cornets
of
horse, w
ch
are
thought to make 900 men.
